sentences_tone.text: Apple: The Teenager Effect - Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksApple: The Teenager EffectNov.11.16 | About: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Edwin Kye Follow Long/short equity, portfolio strategy, large-capSend MessageSummaryBoth data and empirical evidence confirm the iPhone's popularity among teenagers and millennials.There appears to be growing bearish sentiment on Apple, partly due to phones such as the Google Pixel.I'd like to present in this article why these concerns are unfounded and why the iPhone and Apple as a whole still have significant upside potential.I'd like to begin with a disclaimer: this article will lack stringent technical and fundamental analysis of Apple's share price and the company as a whole, mainly due to the fact that there are dozens and dozens of articles on those topics from different authors and websites.
I'd like to present my view on Apple from a different perspective, one that I haven't seen touched upon very frequently.

While most of my articles on this site have revolved around the sportswear and footwear industries, I decided to write an article on Apple as I've picked up on a lot of bearish sentiment about Apple through my frequent perusal of both this website and message boards.

The concern seems to stem from the recent release and media buzz over technologically superior devices like the Google Pixel, with fantastic specs and features that seem to have a chance at giving the iPhone a run for its money.
Popularity Among Teenagers There's no doubt that the iPhone and other Apple products are the devices most desired by teenagers and millennials.
This article cites data from several Piper Jaffray analysts who write that the iPhone's popularity among teenagers is "strong and growing".
According to data collected by these analysts, 75% of teenagers expect their next smartphone to be an iPhone, while approximately 70% of teenagers own an iPhone.
These statistics may be quite odd when you look at the overall smartphone market in the US, of which the iPhone has 40% market share.
Why, one might ask, is there such a large discrepancy in the iPhone's popularity in the overall US market and among teenagers?
I think the answer to this is a very bullish indicator for the long-term prospects of Apple and its shares.
The Peer Pressure Effect Apple's popularity among teenagers is tied primarily to one factor: the iPhone's super-connectedness.
Teenagers spend insane amounts of time texting friends, both individually and through group chats, video chatting via FaceTime, among other activities.
The iPhone and iOS, as a whole, are simply the best platforms to stay connected with one's friends and as such, the iPhone has been and will continue to be the device of choice for teens.
Video chatting on Android devices continues to be a nuisance, with no single built-in option available to users.
Texting on an Android device is arguably inferior to doing so on the iPhone, with its iconic blue bubbles and iPhone-specific features such as read receipts.
Today's teens are simply against green bubbles, and Android as a whole.
iOS 10 marked the introduction of a new, brilliant feature on iPhone that allow users to play games via iMessage.

Games like 8 Ball and Connect Four are now available to be played via text message and fit in smoothly as part of an iMessage conversation, further solidifying the iPhone's position as the "social phone".
The discrepancy between iPhone ownership rates between teenagers and adults can be understood through a look at the overall smartphone market.

Android devices are often much more affordable than iPhones, and if one doesn't care about features like iMessage, FaceTime, and other perks of owning an iPhone, then an Android device presents a cheaper and often technologically superior alternative.

As such, Android devices are more popular among older individuals and late adopters who want a smartphone but don't care enough about the iPhone's "social world" to justify the iPhone's hefty price tag.

The iPhone's social connectedness is the primary reason why the iPhone has remained the best-selling smartphone for almost 10 years now, with no smartphone coming anywhere near replicating its massive commercial success and cultural significance.
Numerous devices have been released over the use that have been dubbed "iPhone killers".
The Samsung Galaxy and Note lines, when they were introduced, created a ton of online buzz.

I was admittedly one of those who believed these phones had a shot at taking the iPhone's throne: why wouldn't iPhone users switch to a device with much better specifications and a large, beautiful screen?

At the time, I didn't understand nor recognize the iPhone's best selling point: the opportunity to enter a world filled with interconnected blue bubbles and group messages, the convenience of not having to download third-party apps for essential features like video chatting.
These seemingly inconsequential but critical features of the iPhone have led to the ranks of die-hard iPhone fanatics who have contributed to Apple's sky-high customer loyalty and retention rates.
This is why technologically superior phones like the Google Pixel will never pose a real threat to iPhone dominance.
The iPhone has never boasted the best specs or the best internal components, nor has Apple made much of an effort to outfit its breadwinner with the most technologically advanced components.

Devices such as the Google Nexus line and the Samsung Galaxy series have wowed some customers over in the past with their fantastic spec sheets yet none have come even remotely close to displacing the iPhone from its throne.
This is due to what I've dubbed "The Teenager Effect", a nod to the iPhone's social connectedness and simplicity.

Conclusion I wrote this article not as an indicator of Apple shares' short or mid-term price movement nor as a comprehensive analysis of the company as a whole, but believe it should be taken as a positive sign for long-term shareholders of Apple.
As the teenagers and millennials I referred to become the adults and grandparents of tomorrow, I believe the iPhone's commercial success and market share will only continue to grow.
Android has posted fantastic market share and growth rates; however, I do feel that this is primarily a product of its saturation and the large number of Android device manufacturers.
I do not believe Android devices, even ones like the Pixel and Galaxy lines that have received a lot of media attention and buzz, will serve as a deterrent to the iPhone's long-term success.
Our world is becoming increasingly social and connected, and the iPhone and Apple, as a whole, is perfectly poised to capitalize on these trends, more so than any other smartphone manufacturer.
Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours.
